advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> M-SERIES BROCHURE - COVER</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Juraj Mucko for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>One of the first 1982 U.S. Advert.<br><br> Advert said <br><br>THE COMMODORE 64 COULD BE THE MICROCOMPUTER INDUSTRY'S OUTSTANDING NEW PRODUCT INTRODUCTION SINCE THE BIRTH OF THIS INDUSTRY. (Shearson / American Express) <br><br><font color="#666666"> The value of a computer is determined by what it can do. What it can do is largely determined by its memory.<br> The Commodore 64's basic RAM is 64K. This amount of power is unusual in a micro at any price.<br> At $595 it is astonishing.<br> Compared with an Apple II+, for instance, the Commodore 64 offers 33% more power and considerably les than 50% of the cost.<br> Compared with anything else, it's even more impressive...<br><br> If you've been waiting for the "computer revolution", consider it as having arrived... </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT (JANUARY 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"A computer for all french people"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> TAPE RECORDER ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>8bs.com</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMO PIC #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>TO-7/70 playing AIRBUS, a flight sim...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT. (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"A TO7 from Thomson fills the empty cells"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NICE AD (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>As computing was a serious and professional subject, the humorus adverts was rare in 1983.<br> This one said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> When I told my Dad about NEC TREK, NEC's new personal computer, he wanted one right away.<br><br> I told him it has 10 programmable function keys; high powered graphic capabilities, powerful Microsoft BASIC included, and a 8-octave programmable musical tone generator.<br><br> He said it has lot of 'fun games'. <br><br> I told him how its memory storage can interface with cassette diskette or cartridge, and how it has a wide variety of of sophisticated software available - important things like financial management package...<br><br> He just challenged me to a game of Protector.<br><br> That's my Dad. I love him, but sometimes I wish he could understand how a kid feels.</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> :-)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>''The memory tool''</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPUTER TERMINAL TO NETWORK STATION</strong></font><br><blockquote>The HiNet local network system allowed data to be transfered at a 256 Kbyte/sec. speed. It was able to run under CP/M or MS/DOS operating systems. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> POWER... IS EXPENSIVE!</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Megabyte Micro was a special version of the Imsai made with 16 x 64 KB RAM boards (Imsai just introduced this card) and a control board called Intelligent Memory Manager. A mapping configurator allowed each user to use its own protected RAM area. <br><br> Prices :<br><br> 64 KB RAM board Kit: <b>$2599</b>, assembled: <b>$3899</b><br> Intelligent Memory Manager board: <b>$299</b>, assembled: <b>$399</b><br><br> To note: in 1977, 1 MB RAM costed... $62384!</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD #1 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Better features, cheaper price, the PC price war has just started.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>''The Best''</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ACORN AD #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><font color="#666666"> Success in the future will depend upon confidence in using new technologies. That's why a computer in the home has to be more than just an interesting diversion or even a useful tool. It has to an investment in tomorrow for you and your children... </font> <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>8bs.com</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT SEPT. 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><font color="#666666"> With over 20 years of experience in producing high quality printers, Epson have now masterminded a fully integrated desktop microcomputer that will more than earn its keep within your business.<br> The QX-IO is capable of performing all the tasks you will ever require of it, quickly and efficiently. Installation of the QX-IO can be carried out with the minimum of interruption, and with its easily understandable keyboard, it is simplicity itself to operate. Having such a diverse range of software packages available such as database from Pearl and office productivity and accountancy from Peachtree with CP/M and multifont BASIC as standard, the QX-IO can supply all the answers whatever your business.<br> Just look at what's on offer: a big memory - 192k upgradable to 256k RAM and all the graphics you'll ever need - and high resolution graphics at that.<br> The ability to communicate easily with other machines, including our own HX-20 and the advantage of using our fine range of printers, make the QX-lO a totally versatile system at a price you'll find impossible to equal.<br> £1735 plus VAT.<br> If you're looking at micros, look at the QX-IO. The system with all the answers. </font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1979 ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, 1981</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> MEMOTECH LEAFLET</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEW ZEALAND AD #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><font color="#666666"> SEGA'S new hard keyboard and new hard disk drive, make Sega even harder to beat.<br> The very latest industry standard 3" diskettes store a massive 328K of information each desk, and operate at speeds far in excess of their older 5 1/4 inch counterparts. Sega's super control station will also enable you to connect to many other attachments such as business printers electronic typewriters even telephone moderns, through it's two additional I/0 ports, for RS232C and parallel interfaces. <br><br> Sega now boasts not only the most sophisticated and easy to learn basic language, the most incredible graphic capabilities, a sensational range of cartridge and cassette games, superb education and applications software written by and for New Zealanders, but also a very sophisticated, fast, small business system, with the state of the art Sega control station. Feel the difference, see the difference, compare the difference, and you too can enjoy the difference of Sega superiority.</font> <br><br> Notice that between numerous superlatives, the advertising agency mistook floppy disk for hard disk drive.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Moffatt</b> from New Zealand</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (SEPT. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The amazing TI-99/4A.<br> A computer for 1800fr"</blockquote>

computer.description:
The Tonto was the same model as the ICL OPD and the Telcom ComputerPhone which was intended for Australian market. Like the ICL version, the Tonto was sold only in the U.K. It was born thanks to a collaborative venture between British Telecom, ICL and Sinclair Research. The designers idea was to build a centralized desktop information system able to access online services, mainframes and other similar systems through the British Telecom network.
It was essentially a Sinclair QL at heart, featuring the same 68008 processor. Applications software were stored in plug-in ROM cartridges or Microdrive tapes. Sadly, both of them were not compatible with QL interfaces and microdrives format and the specific Tonto O.S. couldn't run ordinary software made for the QL, even in BASIC language.
However, the most interesting aspect of the Tonto was its telephony integration. Its internal modem (300 an 1200/75 baud) could manage two telephone lines, and the Tonto, could be used as an intelligent answering machine thanks to its synthesised voice response (but no record capabilities), a Prestel terminal for Videotext services as well as a specialized peripheral and multi-protocols terminal for mainframes. Several interconnected Tonto's also could automatically exchange files and information between them.
Below are prices for the Tonto at is launch, taken from a BT promotional video for the Tonto, dated 29-4-1985.
?1245 Basic Mono Machine ?1375 Basic Mono Machine with Xchange ?1675 Colour Machine ?1805 Colour Machine with Xchange These are all Excluding VAT.
So these are the final prices. ?1462 Basic Mono Machine ?1615 Basic Mono Machine with Xchange ?1968 Colour Machine ?2120 Colour Machine with Xchange
Then you had an optional printer and many optional ROM packs. This was quite an expensive piece of desk accessory in its day. _______________________
Contributors: Pete (UK)
computer.name: Tonto
computer.ports: Custom connectors for ROM pack and Telephony module, Serial printer, RGB Monitor
computer.power: Power is supplied by the monitor
computer.price: ?1,500 at start. Sold to British Telecom staff for ?100 complete when BT stopped to maintain them.
computer.ram: 128 KB, up to 256 KB + 2 KB of battery-backed RAM
computer.rom: 128 KB, up to 320 KB using ROM packs

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> KEYBOARD CLOSE-UP</strong></font><br><blockquote>A demo program cartridge and BASIC cartridge are inserted in both microdrives</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> RUNNING</strong></font><br><blockquote>Pronto and monochrome monitor running Xchange Task Control.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BACK SIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> ROM-pack<br> <b>(2)</b> Serial printer DB9 connector<br> <b>(3)</b> RGB video out and power input DB15 connector. Power is supplied by the monitor<br> <b>(4)</b> Telephony module with two telephone lines<br></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ROM-PACK</strong></font><br><blockquote>The ROM-pack module itself contains Xchange, a 4 elements business applications package originally made by PSION for the Sinclair QL and including QUILL, ABACUS, ARCHIVE and EASEL.<br> Several optional ROM cartridges could be added. Here, Datalink 2, Interfile and Messaging applications are inserted.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote>For more information about Tonto mainboard, see <a href="http://www.old-computers.com/museum/photos.asp?t=1&c=275&st=1" target="_blank">OPD motherboard</a> picture.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CPU BOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote>A piggy-back board carries the 68008 CPU <b>(1)</b>, 4 ROM chips <b>(2)</b> holding the Tonto operating system, and the Texas Instruments TMP5220C speech synthesiser IC <b>(3)</b>, which has 16 KB of custom ROM.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> TAPE CARTRIDGES</strong></font><br><blockquote>Various software on microdrive tape cartridges.<br> Right ones are empty.</blockquote>

computer.sound: TI TMP5220C speech synthesiser / built-in loudspeaker
